data.title: Mohan Joshi Hazir Ho! (1984)
data.meta_description: An old couple, Mohan Joshi and his wife, sues their landlord for not maintaining their 'collapsing' apartment building. For this, they hire two cunning lawyers. The court case drags on for years and the lawyers milk the old couple dry, while they become rich. Back home in the society, the old couple is ridiculed for fighting the landlord, but they fight on nevertheless.
data.text:
I don't see enough people talking about the actors who play Mrs. Joshis. Both of them have really managed to impress me; especially the younger of the lot - the daughter-in-law really had a beautiful presence despite the little time she had, as opposed to the actor who plays her husband, who had the same amount of screen time but failed to leave an impression.

As someone who has interned at the District Court, the reckless nonchalance of both the advocates and the Judge was spot on, but I wish that the Court had a personality of its own. For a film which revolves around the chawl and the court, both of these elements were static.

I can't not talk…

Mohan Joshi, is a simple man, living a simple life in a simple chawl, with his simple family consisting of his wife, two sons, one daughter-in-law, and a grandson. On his way back from the milkman's shop, Mohan Joshi, contemplates, whether to take the path of law and court to get his landlord Kundan Kapadia to fix the ramshackle state of his chawl.

Partnered with a lawyer named Malkani. he embarks on a road to justice.

Resulting in a 6 year long, battle for relevance and sanity. This case loses its themes of justice and quality of life. The lawyers- referred to, once, as "Kaanun ke Jamadar" hits hard. The once, Bidi stealing Malkani, over the course of six years,…
